docs.section_name: Science; Education; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: The teachers were pulling out their hair. Nearly two dozen high school biology teachers sat in a spacious new laboratory here recently, tugging determinedly at strands of their own hair to provide DNA samples they could analyze.
docs.abstract: Dolan DNA Learning Center at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory offers summer program to train new generation of teachers about dramatic shifts in biology, preparing them to initiate students into rapidly changing mysteries of molecular genetics; such programs respond in part to new stress on standards and testing; participants comment; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The teachers were pulling out their hair.    Nearly two dozen high school biology teachers sat in a spacious new laboratory here recently, tugging determinedly at strands of their own hair to provide DNA samples they could analyze....

headline.main: Keeping Heads, and Hair, in Game; Teachers' Ongoing Training Includes DNA Lessons

docs.lead_paragraph: Predictive analytics, and election forecasting in particular, remains a young science. Experts say some of the models could be off 15 to 20 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Information that can be gathered from novel sources, using algorithms, can help determine the best places to spend limited resources.
docs.abstract: The Upshot; Sendhil Mullainathan Economic View column discusses how governments and humanitarians can forego expensive surveys and use satellite images, cell phone usage and other data as low-cost, effective way to pinpoint poverty.
docs.snippet: Information that can be gathered from novel sources, using algorithms, can help determine the best places to spend limited resources....

headline.print_headline: A Dark Sky at Night Tells No Economic Lies
headline.main: Satellite Images Can Pinpoint Poverty Where Surveys Can’t

docs.lead_paragraph: FIFTY years ago, the British mathematician Alan M. Turing predicted that by about the turn of the century, the average person would not have more than a 70 percent chance of distinguishing a human from a computer program trying to imitate a human in a question-and-answer session. At Dartmouth College on Friday, such a test of man- versus machine-made wit proved at least one thing: to err in prediction is very human indeed.
docs.abstract: Despite prediction fifty years ago by British mathematician Alan M Turing that by about the turn of the century the average person would not have more than a 70 percent chance of distinguishing a human from computer program, test of man versus machine at Dartmouth College has cast aside the prediction; in Dartmouth test, none of six computer programs came close to convincing judges that they came from human voice; test was organized by Prof James Moor, computer ethicist who conducted 10th annual competition for Loebner Prise, an award for program that most closely mimics human conversation; most of contestants were programs known as chatterbots, which contain limited knowledge base meant to keep human user occupied in casual conversation; photo of judges (M)
docs.snippet: FIFTY years ago, the British mathematician Alan M. Turing predicted that by about the turn of the century, the average person would not have more than a 70 percent chance of distinguishing a human from a computer program trying to imitate a human ...

docs.lead_paragraph: To improve the public’s appetite for the performing arts, concert halls in China are promoting educational programs and offering discounted tickets.
docs.abstract: Smaller cities in China are struggling to cultivate interest in classical music; lack of funding, poor management of performing arts institutions and insufficient musical education of audiences contribute to problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: A small but growing number of chronically ill students are attending school virtually with robots, which stream two-way video to connect them to the classroom.
docs.abstract: Small but quickly growing number of chronically ill students now attend school virtually with what are called 'remote presence robots;' technology is still expensive and imperfect, but special education advocates say such robots are valuable alternatives to tutoring.
